title: Fueling innovation
subtitle: No other government program is powered 100% by ideas — our sole purpose is to fan the flames of tech innovation, one candle at a time.

sections.title: Fueling innovation
sections.subtitle: No other government program is powered 100% by ideas — our sole purpose is to fan the flames of tech innovation, one candle at a time.

sections.body:
We invest in individual ideas from federal employees about how to improve the government’s use of technology to serve the public. But instead of throwing a large bucket of money at a hypothetical solution, we start small with the exploration and development of those ideas, only moving forward after rigorous analysis that proves the idea will be successful. It’s like venture capital investments — by government, for government — except the return on investment is making government work better for all. 

Many government technology projects fail. Sometimes it’s because the contract wasn’t set up for success. Sometimes projects fail because of budget overruns. And some projects are just duplicative of efforts happening elsewhere. By researching and monitoring the potential impact of each project at several steps along the way — and not being afraid to pull the plug if we discover something won’t be successful — we don’t waste time or resources pursuing deadend projects. We fail fast so we can fall forward.

items.body:
#### We source differently

All our projects come from public servants who submit ideas to see if they can move the needle forward to solve a real problem.

#### We fund differently

The projects use a phased, incremental funding approach, so we can focus investments on the most promising, impactful ideas.

#### We support differently

We complete rigorous analysis to assess ideas before moving them forward, looking at each idea as a learning opportunity —even if it doesn’t come to fruition.

sections.title: We’re different, by design
sections.text: 10x isn’t your average government program — our venture capital model lets us operate a bit outside the box.

sections.body:
## Prioritizing solutions with impact 

At 10x, we recognize that not all ideas will evolve into successful products that will be embraced by users. We look at a lot of ideas and then focus on the ones that can make the biggest difference for the most people, nurturing them with expertise along the way. Solutions developed by 10x have broad applications across the government and provide substantial improvement to how we serve people.

### Because of 10x...

items.text: Benefits applicants can more easily assess their eligibility
USA.gov can better respond to the public’s needs for information
The government has the clearest-ever picture of the federal web experience
Privacy offices can focus more effort on protecting the public’s information
Data practitioners can make smarter use of data in government
Government can more effectively plan and oversee custom technology projects
Users have a more consistent experience with forms on government web pages
AI practitioners can ensure more equitable application of AI tools

sections.body:
## The backstory

10x began as a one-time experiment to bring private sector practices to government. What started in 2015 as a one-time-only Shark Tank-ish competition evolved into a monthly mini-pitch competition based on ideas from employees. We then added more structure and rigor to our investment strategy. Taking everything we’d learned thus far, we founded 10x in 2017 and continue to refine and improve the process — for instance, we now use a four-phased approach, while providing project teams with better guidance and support.   

Tl; dr — we put our money where our mouths are, applying the 10x process of critical thinking and iterative improvement to ourselves as we continue to learn and change our approach to optimize outcomes.

## Exploring our dark side

We continue to apply what we’ve learned, focusing not only on the projects themselves, but also on the bigger picture issues that affect the broader tech community — what we call dark matter.

Dark matter — a concept shamelessly stolen from our friends at NASA, another federal agency that isn’t afraid to think big and try new things — is a way of looking beyond the product to uncover intriguing nuggets of possibility. We ask the questions in the margins, about how we’re working, why we’re working that way, and where we can find the opportunities for transformation.

sections.title: And now for some humble bragging
sections.text: 10x has been recognized for its contribution to smart technology investment and good government.
